title: Investor Targets Bed Bath & Beyond
text:
Bed Bath & Beyond has hundreds of stores around the country and operates the Buybuy Baby and Harmon retail chains. While its shares initially received a boost from the pandemic, they have fallen over the past year and closed Friday at $16.18, not far from where they were three years ago.

The chain has a turnaround plan that includes reducing the number of products in its stores and launching new private-label brands. But that left it vulnerable to supply-chain issues roiling the retail industry and caused it to cede more sales to rivals such as Amazon.com Inc. and Target Corp. Some analysts who initially backed Chief Executive Mark Tritton's plan are now questioning its viability.

Mr. Cohen said in the letter that Bed Bath & Beyond's strategy is failing to stem sustained market-share losses, noting that core sales dropped 14% from a year earlier in the most recent quarter.

He urged the company to narrow the focus of its turnaround plan, maintain the right inventory mix to meet demand and explore a separation of the Buybuy Baby chain or a sale of the entire company.

He wrote that given Buybuy Baby's growth trajectory, it could be valued at several billion dollars.

He also wrote that the entire company could be better off in the hands of a private-equity firm.

He added that the company should better align leadership compensation with results.

Far from a typical activist, Mr. Cohen gained a following after he built a big GameStop stake and in November 2020 criticized the company for moving too slowly toward e-commerce.

He joined the board in January 2021, which contributed to the Reddit-fueled spike in its shares that followed. He took over as chairman in June 2021.

GameStop's shares are trading lower than they were a year ago, closing Friday at $111.66, but roughly 30 times where they were two years ago.

At its peak in January 2021, the stock hit $347.51, giving the company a market value of more than $20 billion. GameStop's market value stands at about $8.5 billion. Its sales have been increasing.

Mr. Cohen said in the letter that given his focus on GameStop, he isn't in a position to become a Bed Bath & Beyond director himself but didn't rule out his firm nominating directors if necessary. The window to nominate directors is open now and closes at the end of next week.

Raised in Montreal, Mr. Cohen co-founded Chewy in 2011. He served as its CEO through 2018 after leading the company to a $3.35 billion sale to PetSmart Inc. In addition to a sizable position in GameStop, RC Ventures has been a large shareholder of Apple Inc. for years.

This isn't the first time that Bed Bath & Beyond has come under activist-shareholder pressure in recent years. Mr. Tritton was named CEO in 2019 after three activists pushed to revamp the board, saying the company hadn't adapted to the rise of e-commerce and shrinking profit margins.

The activists reached a settlement agreement that put four new directors on the company's board.
